intro: Nigella divaricata var. palestina, commonly known as the Palestinian sesame or black cumin, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of North Africa. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its small, dark blue to purple flowers and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, triangular seeds that are often used in traditional medicine and culinary applications. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun, making it adaptable to arid and semi-arid environments. Its botanical features make it an important species in both ecological and agricultural contexts.
